trial_identification.studytitle: Psychotherapy for depression: a comparison of two cognitive treatments
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised trial of cognitive behaviour therapy and schema focused therapy in major depression to reduce depressive symptoms over six months.

interventions.interventions: Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT) versus Schema Focused Therapy (SFT). Duration: 12 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To test the hypothesis that SFT is superior to CBT in achieving sustained change in depression as judged by independent clinician ratings (MADRS)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Over the last 6 months of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: i) To compare SFT with CBT on i) Outcomes
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the weekly sessions.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: ii) Sustained change on a self-report measure (BDI-II) of depressive symptoms
iii) Remission (MADRS & BDI-II<10 for 2 weeks) and recovery (MADRS & BDI-II<10 for 8 weeks).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of weekly sessions and during the following monthly sessions.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Individuals currently experiencing a major depressive episode (DSM-IV). All people accepted into the study need to be free of any centrally acting drugs (except an occasional hypnotic or the oral contraceptive) and who are able to be safely managed with outpatient psychotherapy.
